primair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: Christ voluntarily undergoes ontological transformation into sin and endures physical/psychic torment to neutralize the horror of human sin and achieve reconciliation with God.

subject.identificatie: Jesus Christ (The Divine Son of God)
tekstueel_bewijs: he took upon himself our sins
He met in his death the cost of neutralizing... this unspeakable horror
Christ in love became for us the smell of rotting corruption
Jesus took it all, paid it all, and changed it all

object.identificatie: The neutralization of sin and the restoration of humanity (The Crown of Life)
tekstueel_bewijs: getting rid of this unspeakable horror
He changes the crown of thorns to that crown of life

zender.identificatie: The Mystery of God / Divine Love and Holiness
tekstueel_bewijs: in the mystery of God, he took upon himself our sins
in the mystery of God's love and holiness, Christ became sin
For me! For me! For you! For you!
he gives to all who love him

helper.identificatie: The Holy Spirit (implied via 'mystery') and the Prophetic Word (Isaiah)
tekstueel_bewijs: The words of Isaiah sound sadly appropriate
helper.rol_van_god: God is both Subject (in Christ) and Sender.
helper.rol_van_geest: External help through the 'mystery' of the divine nature.

tegenstander.identificatie: Sin as a Cosmic/Ontological Power and its human agents (Soldiers/Pilate)
tekstueel_bewijs: unspeakable horror which was the sin of the whole world
tegenstander.toelichting_ernst: Sin is described not just as a mistake but as a 'fetid and hideous' ontological reality that requires the Subject to 'become' it to destroy it.

secundair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The hearer is called to avoid 'fixing' things (dishonesty) and to guard their humor against mocking the holy.
secundair_narratief_programma.subject: The Hearer
secundair_narratief_programma.toelichting_verhouding: The ethical warnings regarding Pilate's 'fixing' and the soldiers' 'humor' serve as negative exemplars contrasted against Christ's sacrifice.

actantieel_schema_visualisatie.zender_naar_ontvanger: Divine Love → Salvation/Crown of Life → The Hearer

voorbeelden_god_subject: He met in his death the cost.
Jesus took it all, paid it all, and changed it all.
voorbeelden_mens_subject: We must watch this tendency to 'fix' things.
Think now of the most sinful thing you have ever done.

voorbeelden: We must watch this tendency to 'fix' things.
Pilate... had a legal and a moral responsibility.
Let us think... of the most sinful thing.
I wish these rude soldiers... could know.
you will begin... to understand what our Lord suffered.
He changed and changes curses to prayers.
He changes the poison of sin into a medicine of grace.

modale_analyse.modale_interpretatie: The sermon emphasizes Christ's 'Power to do' (Pouvoir-faire) what man cannot—transforming the ontological state of sin into grace.

semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.beweging_in_preek: The sermon moves from the horror of S2 (Sin) to the mockery of ~S1, then shows Christ entering S2 to bring about ~S2, finally resolving in the triumph of S1.
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.theologische_resolutie: Substitutionary atonement: Christ becomes S2 to exhaust its power.
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.ernst_van_s2: Extremely high; sin is described in visceral, repulsive terms.

diagnostische_evaluatie.classificatie_toelichting: The sermon is profoundly theocentric. While it contains ethical warnings, the 'engine' of the narrative is Christ's active work upon a passive/receptive humanity.

indicatoren_moralisme.tekstueel_bewijs: We must watch this tendency to 'fix' things.

indicatoren_genade.tekstueel_bewijs: Jesus took it all, paid it all, and changed it all.
rotting corruption... loathsome and fetid and hideous.

exemplarisme_check.beschrijving: Pilate and the soldiers are used as negative examples of behavior to avoid (dishonesty and mocking).
exemplarisme_check.alternatieve_lezing: The sermon already subordinates these examples to the primary work of Christ.

identificatie_patroon.effect_op_hoorder: Relief and awe; the 'For me!' refrain encourages passive reception of a finished work.
identificatie_patroon.theologische_implicatie: Monergistic salvation; Christ is the sole actor in the drama of redemption.

narratieve_coherentie.coherentie_beschrijving: The transition from the 'horror of sin' to the 'triumph of grace' is logically and narratively tight.
spanning_punten: The brief moral exhortation on humor feels slightly disconnected from the high-soteriological tone of the rest of the text.

soteriologie.tekstueel_bewijs: Christ became sin... he took upon himself in his death all of humanity's distasteful, repugnant sins.

pneumatologie.competentie_schenking: The sermon focuses on Christ's performance rather than the Spirit's application.

hamartologie.ernst_diagnose: Critical; sin is a 'poison' and 'corruption' that humans cannot fix.

aanbevelingen.actantiele_audit_samenvatting: The sermon successfully maintains Christ as the Subject of the primary narrative. The hearer is correctly positioned as the Receiver.

identificatie_herstel.problematische_identificatie: The hearer might briefly identify with the 'moral fixer' (Pilate) in a way that distracts from the cross.
identificatie_herstel.voorgestelde_identificatie: The 'smitten' who is healed by the stripes.
identificatie_herstel.strategie: Link the 'fixing' tendency more explicitly to the sin Christ 'became' on the cross.

modale_balans.voorgestelde_balans: Maintain current balance; it is highly effective for a Passion sermon.
modale_balans.concrete_suggestie: Ensure the 'must' of the ethical section is clearly grounded in the 'has done' of the cross.

aanbevelingen.slotopmerking: This is a powerful example of a grace-oriented sermon where the narrative 'engine' is entirely driven by the agency of Christ.

comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_retorische_analyse: While a rhetorical analysis would focus on the evocative imagery of 'rotting corruption,' Greimas' analysis shows that these images function as a 'Heavy Opponent' to justify the necessity of a Divine Subject.
comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_exegese: Exegesis would focus on the Roman custom of scourging; actantial analysis focuses on how the 'Soldiers' function as actants of humiliation that Christ (Subject) must overcome.
comparatieve_analyse.unieke_inzichten_greimas: Reveals that the 'For me!' refrain is a linguistic marker of the 'Receiver' actant, confirming the sermon's non-moralistic structure.

appendices.notities: The sermon uses high-contrast actantial roles to emphasize the 'Subject-switch' from human failure to divine victory.
